text: I'm Drew.
And this is Lisa.

And we're working on
Argus Systems together.

You're probably wondering
why I'm holding a beach ball.

This beach ball
represents the amount

of data that was required
to train ChatGPT 3.5.

This golf ball here
represents the largest data

set available to train
something similar
that we have for robotics.

I know that every
single one of us

probably wants a robot doing
our chores and our laundry.

But to get there, we
don't have enough data.

We're going to need
a lot more data.
And that's where we come in.

Argus Systems scales
training data collection
and labeling for physical AI.

So we're going to buy
robots, do stuff with them,

like fold laundry, and
collect the sensor data--

sell those data sets to
companies so that you don't have
to fold your laundry anymore.
And trust me, I hate laundry.

Before coming to HBS, I
served in the Marine Corps
for six years.

And during that
time period, I also

got a master's that taught
me the fundamentals of AI
and machine learning.

And that ultimately led
me here to HBS, where
I met Lisa, through Section G.
[CHEERS]

As for me, I studied
robotics at Carnegie Mellon,

and was most recently a
software engineer at Waymo,

where I worked on the
perception data labeling system.

And finally, I'll leave
you with an apology.

So I'm sorry to say that we're
contributing to the HBS's

unemployment statistic and
working on this full-time

after graduation
in San Francisco.

But we couldn't be
more excited to do so.

So thank you so much,
everyone, for supporting us.
[APPLAUSE]
